column6: Changes in release 208 seem to have more than doubled the speed for CSVWrite for large files. Average time to execute CSVWrite(Data, FileName) when Data is obtained from RDataSets file military.csv (1.4 million rows, 7 cols) falls from 24 seconds to 11 seconds.

Bumped to v0.24

Changed CSVWrite so that when called on PC for which the display language of VBA is not English, then errors are written to file using the English-language representation (e.g. #SPILL!). This makes round-tripping work correctly.
Further changes to ReThrow. Error strings from CSVRead and CSVWrite are now concise unless m_ErrorStringsEmbedCallStack is set to True.
Change to expected results for tests to soft code the string representation of True and False, so that tests pass on non English language PCs.

a) Removed module modCodeFromStackOverflow.
b) Simplified methods Throw and ReThrow, as a consequence error string now include the "call stack".
c) Changes to tests such that if observed and expected are both error strings that differ but have the same "root cause" then the test passes but with a warning printed to the VBA immediate window.
d) Removed declared-but-unused variables (via MZTools).
e) Changes to round trip testing to pass in TrueStrings and FalseStrings such that tests should work on non English-language PC.
Added Test254 for a file containing only two characters - a carriage return and a line feed, but test currently fails - need to investigate.
Change to (hopefully) fix bug on non English-language version of Excel. Passing ConvertTypes as True failed on PC with display language of German. Not yet tested though.

Added line numbers to modCSVReadWrite. These will appear in the call stack only for unanticipated errors, i.e. the kind we need to debug.
Reformed error handling in all the modules.

Reformed error handling. Error handlers in all methods are now simpler just calling new method ReThrow. We now no longer see the "call stack" in the return from CSVRead if the error is "anticipated" (mostly input validation) but we do see the call stack for unanticipated errors.
Ensure streams are always closed.
CSVRead now always uses ADODB text stream (rather than ADODB for some encodings and Scripting.TextStream for other encodings). Refactored and simplified.

Refactored method ParseEncoding. Previously there were two places in the code where we decided whether to use a TextStream or ADODB (according to whether the Encoding argument had been provided or had to be guessed\inferred), now only one place.

Method InferDelimiter could fail for UTF-8 and UTF-16 files (the BOM was being read as part of the file's contents). Fixed this.

Round trip tests extended to test various DateTimeFormats. Amended CSVWrite to recognise "ISO" as a DateFormat (was confusing for that to be recognised as DateTimeFormat but not as DateFormat).

More testing of CSVWrite - important to test aspects of CSVWrite that are not tested in the round-trip tests, e.g. invalid inputs and behaviour when returning to worksheet and when QuoteAllStrings is FALSE.

CSVWrite was not correctly handling argument QuoteAllStrings when the delimiter was not a comma. CSVRead fix to another edge case re ragged files and ShowMissingsAs.

CSVRead: Now reject elements of TrueStrings, FalseStrings and MissingStrings that are not valid fields of a CSV file. Added tests 209 to 232 (to increase code coverage). Use & instead of + for string concatenation. Fixed edge case in CSVRead with regards to missing fields in ragged files.

Removed commented-out module modCSVDevUtils. Tweak to method ValidateBooleanRepresentation. Amended variable declaration (automatically, via a script).

Tweaks to CSVWrite including changed behaviour if DateFormat is passed as null string (as opposed to being omitted). Old behaviour: date format used in output would depend on the Windows locale. New behaviour: date format used is YYYY-MM-DD, i.e. same as omitting the argument.

CSVRead: better handling for when Booleans in file are represented by quoted strings. E.g. https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/carData/TitanicSurvival.csv where the TrueString is quoted yes and FalseString is quoted no.

2) Argument DateFormat can now use the space character as the separator. e.g. "D M Y" is allowed. Test = 204.

In release 120 (or soon after) I followed suggestions from RubberDuck code analysis to explicitly declare all arguments as ByVal or ByRef with preference for ByVal. But I now believe that caused a performance hit, especially when ConvertTypes is not FALSE. Reverted declarations to as of version 119. I now declare as follows:
ByVal = argument will be changed in function and we don't want that change to be visible to the caller.
ByRef = argument will be changed in function and we DO want that change to be visible to the caller.
Silent = argument won't be changed in the function, so pass by reference (the default) for better speed.
